[[File:Southern Sudan Geology Map-es.svg|thumb|right|300px|Geologic map of South Sudan]] The '''geology of [[South Sudan]]''' is founded on [[Precambrian]] igneous and metamorphic rocks, that cover 40 percent of the country's surface and underlie other rock units. The region was affected by the [[Pan-African orogeny]] in the [[Neoproterozoic]] and extensional tectonics in the [[Mesozoic]] that deposited very thick oil-bearing sedimentary sequences in rift basins. Younger basalts, sandstones and sediments formed in the last 66 million years of the [[Cenozoic]]. The discovery of oil in 1975 was a major factor in the [[Second Sudanese Civil War]], leading up to independence in 2011. The country also has gold, copper, cobalt, zinc, iron, marble, limestone and dolomite.
==Stratigraphy & geologic history== The oldest rocks in South Sudan are [[Precambrian]] [[gneiss]], metasediments and basic volcanics that form the igneous and metamorphic basement rock that underlies the country and is exposed as 40 percent of its surface. Some Precambrian rocks may be well over two billion years old. However, in most cases they were reactivated and altered in the [[Neoproterozoic]] [[Pan-African orogeny]].
Northwest South Sudan has the [[Mesozoic]] [[Cretaceous]] Nubian sandstone overlying basement rock. Much of northern South Sudan is underlain by deep, oil-bearing rift basins, with sedimentary rocks up 13.7 kilometers thick. Lacustrine shales, claystones, sandstones and conglomerates formed in the [[Jurassic]] and [[Cretaceous]]. Alluvial sediments formed in the past 2.5 million years of the [[Quaternary]] flank major rivers in the north, center and east. The [[Cenozoic]] [[Um Ruwaba Formation]] covers most of central and eastern South Sudan and [[basalt]], also from the Cenozoic occurs close to the border with Ethiopia. <ref>{{cite article |title=Hydrogeology of South Sudan|publisher=British Geological Survey|url=http://earthwise.bgs.ac.uk/index.php/Hydrogeology_of_South_Sudan#Geology}}</ref> <ref>{{cite book |author=Schluter, Thomas |year=2006|title=Geological Atlas of Africa|publisher=Springer|p=230-231}}</ref>
==Hydrogeology== Most of southwest South Sudan is underlain by low productivity Precambrian basement rock. Sedimentary aquifers with intergranular flow are found in the northwest, abutting a large area spanning most of the north and center of the country with unconsolidated alluvial sediments. Modest areas of fractured volcanic with a range of water productivity are found near the Ethiopian border. <ref>{{cite article |title=Hydrogeology of South Sudan|publisher=British Geological Survey|url=http://earthwise.bgs.ac.uk/index.php/Hydrogeology_of_South_Sudan#Hydrogeology}}</ref>
==Natural resource geology== Alluvial gold is relatively common in South Sudan and is often extracted through artisanal mining. Copper and gold ore, associated with radioactive minerals, occurs at Hofrat Ennahas in Western Bahr El Ghazal state, and has been explored by major companies such as Billington.
[[Bauxite]] layers between four and 20 meters thick formed in [[laterite]] east of [[Juba]], west of Wau and west of Yambio. Often, a 10 to 30 meter thick section of iron ore overlies bauxite, particularly west of Wau and close to the border of Central African Republic and Sudan. South Sudan also has zinc, manganese, lead, nickel and cobalt. The country has marble, limestone and dolomite but no active cement plants. The Kapoeta marble is proposed as a source for cement, to overcome the very high $640 US dollar per ton of imported cement. <ref>{{cite article |author=Adde, Andu Ezbon |year=2013|title=Geology and Mineral Investment Opportunities in South Sudan|publisher=Republic of South Sudan-Ministry of Petroleum & Mining|url=https://www.slideshare.net/miningontop/mota-2013-south-sudan-presentation}}</ref>
Prior to South Sudanese independence in 2011, Chevron Overseas Petroleum launched a major survey of unstudied rift basins in the interior of Sudan in 1975. The survey revealed up to 300 billion barrels of oil housed in extremely thick sediment sequences in [[Heglig]] and [[Unity State]]. The development of the oil industry was a major factor in the [[Second Sudanese Civil War]]. <ref>{{cite article |author=Schull, T. J. |year=1988|title=Rift Basins of Interior Sudan: Petroleum Exploration and Discovery|publisher=AAPG Bulletin|url=http://archives.datapages.com/data/bulletns/1988-89/data/pg/0072/0010/1100/1128.htm}}</ref>
==References== {{portal|Geology|South Sudan|Prehistory of Africa}} {{commonscat|Geology of South Sudan}} {{reflist}} {{Clear}}
{{Africa topic|Geology of}}
[[Category:Geology of South Sudan| ]] [[Category:Geology by country|South Sudan]]

revision.text:
The '''International Map of the World''' (also called the '''Millionth Map''', after its [[map scale|scale]] of 1:1000000) was a project begun in 1913 to create a complete [[World map|map of the world]] according to internationally agreed standards. Roads were depicted in red, towns and railways were depicted in black, and the labels were written in the Roman alphabet.{{cite web |title = International Map of the World |url = http://geography.about.com/od/historyofgeography/a/millionthmap.htm}} The map was the brainchild of [[Albrecht Penck]], a German geographer who first proposed it in 1891.{{cite book|title=Great maps.|date=2014|publisher=Dk Publishing|location=[S.l.]|isbn=978-1-4654-2463-1|page=212}} The Central Bureau of the Map of the World was established at the [[Ordnance Survey]] in London. After the [[Second World War]], the [[United Nations]] took over the project. By 1953 only 400 of about 1000 sheets had been produced; though this covered most of the land surface outside North America, many sheets were decades out of date, and almost none of the open ocean was covered.Pearson et al 2006, p.162 In 1964, [[Arthur H. Robinson]] dismissed the IMW as "cartographic wallpaper" of no practical use.{{cite journal|last=Robinson|first=A. H.|date=18 July 2013|origyear=1965|title=The Future of the International Map|journal=The Cartographic Journal|volume=2|issue=1|pages=23–26|doi=10.1179/caj.1965.2.1.23|issn=0008-7041}} There were few updates thereafter, and in 1989, [[UNESCO]] declared the project was no longer feasible and stopped monitoring it.Pearson et al 2006, p.163 ==Map indexing system{{anchor|Map Indexing System}}== [[File:Soviet topographic map codes.svg|thumb|400px|Map index of northern and central Asia. Since it lies entirely north of the equator, prefix map index numbers with '''N'''.
Note longitudinal span increasing to 12° at 60°N, then to 24° at 76°N.]] [[File:North-East part of Caspian Sea (IMW NL39).jpg|thumb|400px|Map '''NL 39''']] A [[map indexing system]] was developed for dividing the globe into sections spanning six degrees of longitude by four degrees latitude. {{Cite web |title = The International Map of the World and its Numbering System |url = http://www.icsm.gov.au/mapping/maps_topographic.html#imw |accessdate = 2011-06-26}} Longitudinal slices are numbered 1 (180-174°West) through 60 (174-180°East). Latitudinal slices are named NA (0-4°North) through NV (84-88°North) and SA (0-4°South) through SV (84-88°South). For example * Map NJ-10 {{Cite map |publisher = U.S.A. Corps of Engineers. Army Map Service |title = '''NJ 10''' San Francisco Bay |url = http://www.lib.utexas.edu/maps/imw/txu-oclc-6654394-nj-10-3rd-ed.jpg |year = 1962 |scale = 1:1 million |series = World (North America) |accessdate = 2011-06-26}} covers 36-40°N, 120-126°W including [[San Francisco]] at {{coord|37|47|N|122|25|W}}. * SG-35 {{Cite map |publisher = ...[[Army Map Service]] |title = '''SG 35''' Johannesburg |url = http://www.lib.utexas.edu/maps/imw/txu-oclc-6654394-sg-35-1st-ed.jpg |year = c. 1962 |series = World (Africa)}} covers 24-28°S, 24-30°E including [[Johannesburg]] at {{coord|26|12|S|28|03|E}}. * NL-38(below, right) covers 44-48N, 48-54E including [[Astrakhan]] at {{coord|46|19|N|48|2|E}}. * NI-54 {{Cite map |publisher = ...[[Army Map Service]] |title = '''NI 54''' Tokyo |url = http://www.lib.utexas.edu/maps/imw/txu-oclc-6654394-ni-54-3rd-ed.jpg |year = 1957 |series = World (Asia)}} covers 32-36°N, 138-144°E including [[Tokyo]] at {{coord|35|42|N|139|43|E}}. Due to shortening of longitudinal distances with increasing latitude, longitudinal span beyond 60 degrees latitude doubles to twelve degrees. Beyond 76 degrees it doubles again to 24 degrees. This indexing system outlived the international project and is still used in national and international mapping programs by Australia, {{Cite web |title = Topographic Maps |url = http://www.icsm.gov.au/mapping/maps_topographic.html |accessdate = 2011-06-26}} Russia and the United States. {{Cite web |url = http://www.lib.utexas.edu/maps/imw/ |title = International Map of the World 1:1,000,000 |author = ...[[Army Map Service]]. |publisher = University of Texas at Austin |accessdate = 2011-06-26 }} ==See also== * [[World Aeronautical Chart]], another millionth world map * [[World Map 1:2,500,000]], a similar Soviet-Eastern Bloc project * [[Digital Chart of the World]], vector dataset ==References== ===Sources=== * {{cite journal |last1=Pearson|first1=Alastair |last2=Taylor |first2=D. R. Fraser |last3=Kline|first3=Karen D. |last4=Heffernan|first4=Michael |year=2006|title=Cartographic ideals and geopolitical realities: international maps of the world from the 1890s to the present|journal=The Canadian Geographer|volume=50|issue=2|pages=149–176|issn=0008-3658|doi=10.1111/j.0008-3658.2006.00133.x}} * {{cite journal|last=Pearson|first=Alastair W. |first2=Michael |last2=Heffernan |year=2 January 2015 |title=Globalizing Cartography? The International Map of the World, the International Geographical Union, and the United Nations|journal=Imago Mundi|volume=67|issue=1|pages=58–80|issn=1479-7801|doi=10.1080/03085694.2015.974956|url=http://www.tandfonline.com/doi/pdf/10.1080/03085694.2015.974956 |format=PDF |accessdate=4 October 2016 }} ===Citations=== {{reflist}} ==External links== * [http://www.lib.utexas.edu/maps/imw/ International Map of the World 1:1,000,000] index to scans at the [[Perry-Castañeda Library Map Collection]] {{Commons category|International Map of the World}} {{DEFAULTSORT:International Map Of The World}} [[Category:World maps]] [[Category:Map series]] [[Category:Geocodes]] {{cartography-stub}}

{{Infobox person | name = Josefina Gómez Mendoza | image = | alt = | caption = | birth_name = | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1942|06|01|df=yes}} | birth_place = [[Madrid]], Spain | death_date = | death_place = | death_cause = | other_names = | occupation = Academic | organization = {{Plainlist| * [[Real Academia de la Historia|Royal Academy of History]] * [[Royal Academy of Engineering of Spain|Royal Academy of Engineering]] }} | years_active = | known_for = | notable_works = | spouse = | children = | awards = {{Plainlist| * [[Civil Order of Alfonso X, the Wise|Grand Cross of the Civil Order of Alfonso X, the Wise]] (2002) * {{ill|Medal for Merit at Work|es|Medalla al Mérito en el Trabajo|lt=Gold Medal for Merit at Work}} (2008) }} | alma_mater = [[Complutense University of Madrid]] | website = {{Official URL}} }} '''Josefina Gómez Mendoza''' (born 1 June 1942) is a Spanish geographer, writer, and professor emerita.<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.colegiodeemeritos.es/Profesores/ProfesoresActuales_GomezMendozaJosefina/seccion=62&idioma=es_ES&id=2011100612200001&activo=7.do |title=Josefina Gómez Mendoza |publisher=Colegio Libre de Eméritos |language=Spanish |access-date=20 August 2018}}</ref> From 2001 to 2005 she was Rector of the [[National University of Distance Education]] (UNED). She is a member of the [[Real Academia de la Historia|Royal Academy of History]], Medal No. 7 (elected 8 February 2002, took office 27 April 2003),<ref name=Historia>{{Cite news |url=https://elpais.com/diario/2002/02/09/cultura/1013209205_850215.html |title=La geógrafa Josefina Gómez Mendoza, elegida académica de la Historia |trans-title=The Geographer Josefina Gómez Mendoza, Elected Academic of History |work=[[El País]] |location=Madrid |language=Spanish |date=9 February 2002 |access-date=20 August 2018}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.rah.es/da-josefina-gomez-mendoza/ |title=Josefina Gómez Mendoza |publisher=[[Real Academia de la Historia|Royal Academy of History]] |language=Spanish |access-date=20 August 2018}}</ref> and the [[Royal Academy of Engineering of Spain|Royal Academy of Engineering]], Medal No. 58 (took office 21 March 2006).<ref name=Engineering>{{Cite web |url=http://www.raing.es/es/acad-micos/excma-sra-d-josefina-g-mez-mendoza |title=Excma. Sra. Dña. Josefina Gómez Mendoza |publisher=[[Royal Academy of Engineering of Spain]] |language=Spanish |access-date=20 August 2018}}</ref>
==Career== Josefina Gómez Mendoza holds a [[Licentiate (degree)#Spain|licentiate]] in Philosophy and Literature from History Department at the [[Complutense University of Madrid]] (1974), as well as a Doctorate in Philosophy and Literature from the same university's History and Geography Department.
In 1978 she was assistant professor of geography by examination, and in 1979 she was an associate professor. In 1981 she won the access competition for the Geography Chair of Spain.
From 1985 to 2012 she was Professor of Regional Geographical Analysis at the [[Autonomous University of Madrid]].
In June 2005 she was named [[Doctor Honoris Causa]] of the [[Charles III University of Madrid]] and invested on 3 February 2006.
In September 2012, she was appointed Chair Emerita at the Autonomous University of Madrid. That October she was also named Professor Emerita of the Autonomous University, and that November she was named Doctor Honoris Causa by the [[École normale supérieure de Lyon]].<ref name=Lyon>{{Cite book |url=http://www.ens-lyon.fr/sites/default/files/2018-03/Livret_HE%20Mingyuan.pdf |title=Cérémonie de Doctorat Honoris Causa |publisher=[[École normale supérieure de Lyon]] |page=2 |language=French |date=12 May 2016 |access-date=20 August 2018}}</ref>
Gómez Mendoza was an elective State Councilor from 2003 to 2008 and from 2008 to 2013. She has been a Member of the National Council of National Parks since 2008.<ref name=Engineering/>
She was President of the Association of Spanish Geographers from 1993 to 1997.
In addition to publishing several books, she has written for some media outlets, including the newspaper ''[[El País]]''.<ref>{{Cite web |url=https://elpais.com/autor/josefina_gomez_mendoza/a/ |title=Articles by Josefina Gómez Mendoza |work=[[El País]] |language=Spanish |access-date=20 August 2018}}</ref>
==Books== * 1977, ''Agricultura y expansión urbana: la campiña del bajo Henares en la aglomeración de Madrid'', {{ISBN|9788420621920}} * 1982, ''El pensamiento geográfico: estudio interpretativo y antología de textos'' * 1982, ''Viajeros y paisajes'' * 1992, ''Ciencia y política de los montes españoles (1848–1936)'' * 1999, ''Los paisajes de Madrid (Naturaleza y Medio Rural)'', {{ISBN|9788420644882}}
==Awards and honors== * 1998: Gold Medal of the Autonomous University of Madrid<ref name=Historia/> * 2002: [[Civil Order of Alfonso X, the Wise|Grand Cross of the Civil Order of Alfonso X, the Wise]]<ref name=Alfonso>{{Cite web |url=http://noticias.universia.es/vida-universitaria/noticia/2002/06/14/634082/concede-gran-cruz-alfonso-x-sabio-salustiano-campo-emilio-fernandez-galiano-josefina-gomez-mendoza-carlos-seco-serrano.html |title=Se concede la Gran Cruz de Alfonso X el Sabio a Salustiano del Campo, Emilio Fernández-Galiano, Josefina Gómez Mendoza y Carlos Seco Serrano |trans-title=The Grand Cross of Alfonso X the Wise is Awarded to Salustiano del Campo, Emilio Fernández-Galiano, Josefina Gómez Mendoza, and Carlos Seco Serrano |publisher=[[Universia]] |language=Spanish |date=14 June 2002 |access-date=20 August 2018}}</ref> * 2005: Doctor Honoris Causa of the Charles III University of Madrid * 2009: {{ill|Medal for Merit at Work|es|Medalla al Mérito en el Trabajo|lt=Gold Medal for Merit at Work}}<ref>{{Cite journal |url=https://www.boe.es/diario_boe/txt.php?id=BOE-A-2008-19795 |title=Real Decreto 2038/2008 |work=[[Boletín Oficial del Estado]] |number=294 |page=48980 |language=Spanish |date=6 December 2008 |access-date=20 August 2018}}</ref> * 2011: Fernando González Bernáldez Distinction from the González Bernáldez Foundation<ref>{{Cite web |url=https://www.uam.es/ss/Satellite/en/1242649910548/1242657908589/noticia/noticia/Josefina_Gomez_Mendoza,_catedratica_de_Geografia_de_la_UAM,__recibe_la__distincion_Fernando_Gonzalez.htm |title=Josefina Gómez Mendoza, catedrática de Geografía de la UAM, recibe la distinción Fernando González Bernáldez |trans-title=Josefina Gómez Mendoza, Geography Chair at UAM, Receives the Fernando González Bernáldez Distinction |publisher=[[Autonomous University of Madrid]] |language=Spanish |date=19 October 2011 |access-date=20 August 2018}}</ref> * 2012: Doctor Honoris Causa of the École normale supérieure de Lyon<ref name=Lyon/> * Diego de Saavedra Fajardo Award for Geography, Economics, Sociology, and Literature<ref name=Alfonso/> * [[Ordre des Palmes Académiques]]<ref name=Historia/>

{{infobox person/Wikidata | fetchwikidata=ALL|list=hlist|dateformat=mdy}} '''Fredrick Kenneth Hare''', {{Post-nominals|country=CAN|CC|OOnt|FRSC}} (February 5, 1919 – September 3, 2002) was a [[Canadians|Canadian]] climatologist and [[academic]], who researched atmospheric [[carbon dioxide]], [[climate change]], [[drought]], and arid zone climates and was a strong advocate for preserving the [[natural environment]].
== Biography == Born in [[Wiltshire]], [[England]], he received a [[Bachelor of Science]] in 1939 from [[King's College London]]. During [[World War II]], he was a meteorologist with the UK [[Air Ministry]], and joined [[McGill University]] as an assistant professor after the war. In 1950, he received a [[PhD]] in Geography from the [[Université de Montréal]].<ref>{{cite web | title = F. Kenneth Hare | date = September 17, 2015 | website = science.ca | publisher = GCS Research Society | url = http://www.science.ca/scientists/scientistprofile.php?pID=168 | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20160614221531/http://www.science.ca/scientists/scientistprofile.php?pID=168 | archivedate = June 14, 2016 | dead-url = no | accessdate = June 14, 2016}}</ref>
===Scientific career=== Hare was Dean of Arts and Science at McGill starting 1962 before returning to England in 1964. He was Master of [[Birkbeck, University of London|Birkbeck College]] from 1966 to 1968, during which he served as president of the [[Royal Meteorological Society]].<ref>{{cite web | url= https://www.rmets.org/about-us/history-society/society-presidents | title= Society Presidents | series = History of the Society | publisher = Royal Meteorological Society | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20160614224606/https://www.rmets.org/about-us/history-society/society-presidents | archive-date = June 14, 2016 | dead-url = no | accessdate = June 14, 2016}}</ref>
In 1968, he accepted the position as fifth president of the [[University of British Columbia]], which he served until he resigned on January 31, 1969.<ref>{{cite web | title = Former UBC President Kenneth Hare Remembered | department = UBC Reports | publication-date = September 22, 2006 | publisher = The University of British Columbia | date = October 10, 2002 | url = http://news.ubc.ca/ubcreports/2002/02oct10/hare.html | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20160614224313/http://news.ubc.ca/ubcreports/2002/02oct10/hare.html | archive-date = June 14, 2016 | dead-url = no | accessdate = June 14, 2016}}</ref> He joined the [[University of Toronto]] (U of T) becoming a Professor of geography and physics in 1974. From 1974 to 1979 he was director of the Institute for Environmental Studies at the U of T. From 1979 until 1986 he was [[provost (education)|Provost]] of [[University of Trinity College|Trinity College]]. From 1988 to 1995 he was the sixth Chancellor of [[Trent University]].<ref>{{cite web | title = Trent University Mourns the Death of Former Chancellor Dr. Kenneth Hare | department = Communications Office | publisher = Trent University | date = September 16, 2002 | series = Daily News | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20160614225003/http://www.trentu.ca/news/daily/archive/khare.html | archive-date = June 14, 2016 | dead-url = no | url = http://www.trentu.ca/news/daily/archive/khare.html | accessdate = June 14, 2016}}</ref> From 1992 until his death in 2002, he chaired Canada's national Climate Program Planning Board.
== Research interests and advocacy == Hare's research interests included atmospheric carbon dioxide, climate change, drought, and arid zone climates. He was a strong advocate of protecting the natural environment and served on a wide variety of commissions and committees on subjects that included [[acid rain]], [[desertification]], [[heavy metals]], [[nuclear reactors]] (and their waste products), [[ozone]], [[greenhouse gases]] and [[climate change]]. He was on the Research and Development Advisory Panel of [[Atomic Energy of Canada]] and conducted studies on nuclear waste management in [[Sweden]] and [[France]].
Hare considered that the most pressing environmental challenge facing Canada is climate change caused by excessive use of [[fossil fuels]]. He advocated effectively managed nuclear power as a viable alternative. Throughout his life Hare was a tireless public speaker and writer about these issues.
== Awards and honours == Hare received the [[Massey Medal]] in 1974. In 1978 he was made an Officer of the [[Order of Canada]] and was promoted to Companion in 1987.<ref>{{cite web | title = F. Kenneth Hare, C.C., Ph.D., D.Sc., F.R.S.C. | website = The Governor General of Canada | publisher = Office of the Secretary to the Governor General | year = 2016 | url = http://www.gg.ca/honour.aspx?id=721&t=12&ln=Hare | accessdate = June 14, 2016}}</ref>
In 1987, he was presented with the Sir John William Dawson Medal, for important contributions of knowledge in multiple domains, from the [[Royal Society of Canada]] in which he was a Fellow. The same year, he was awarded the [[Cullum Geographical Medal]] by the [[American Geographical Society]].
In 1989, he received the [[Order of Ontario]] and the [[International Meteorological Organization Prize]] from the [[World Meteorological Organization]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.wmo.int/pages/about/awards/winners_imo_en.html |title=Winners of the IMO Prize |publisher=World Meteorological Organization |accessdate=8 December 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151122014635/http://www.wmo.int/pages/about/awards/winners_imo_en.html |archivedate=22 November 2015 |df= }}</ref> He was awarded honorary degrees by 11 universities.
== References ==
<references/>
{{s-start}} {{s-aca}} {{succession box | before= [[Horace Noel Fieldhouse]] | title= Dean of Arts and Science at [[McGill University]] | years=1962–1964| after= [[Harry Woods Douglas]] }} {{succession box | before= [[John B. Macdonald]] | title=[[University President|President]] of the [[University of British Columbia]] | years=1968–1969| after=[[Walter Gage]] }} {{succession box| before=[[George Ignatieff]]| title=[[Provost (education)|Provost]] of the [[University of Trinity College]]| years=1979–1986| after=[[Robert H. Painter]]| }} {{succession box | before=[[John Josiah Robinette]] | title=[[Chancellor (education)|Chancellor]] of [[Trent University]] | years=1988–1995 | after=[[Mary Simon (ITK)|Mary Simon]] }} {{s-end}}

{{Infobox protected area | name = Kragga Kamma Game Park | alt_name = | iucn_category = | photo = Kragga_Kamma_Giraffe-001.jpg | photo_alt = | photo_caption = [[South African giraffe]] calf suckling on mother | photo_width = | map = South Africa Eastern Cape | relief = 1 | map_alt = | map_caption = | map_width = | location = [[Eastern Cape]], [[South Africa]] | nearest_city = [[Port Elizabeth]] | coordinates = {{coord|33.988|S|25.457|E|region:ZA-EC|format=dms|display=inline,title}} | area = {{convert|203|ha|abbr=on}}<ref>{{cite book|title=Nelson Mandela Bay Municipality Draft Bioregional Plan|date=December 2010|publisher=SRK Consulting (Pty) Ltd|pages=22|url=http://www.nelsonmandelabay.gov.za/Documents.aspx?objID=85&cmd=download&docID=900|accessdate=25 July 2011|chapter=2.7 Ecosystem Protection Level within the Nelson Mandela Bay Municipal Area}}</ref> | established = 2001<ref name=peherald-march2011>{{cite news|last=Rogers|first=Guy|title=PE rhinos dehorned to foil poachers|url=http://www.peherald.com/news/article/1022|accessdate=25 July 2011|newspaper=The Herald (Port Elizabeth)|date=31 March 2011}}</ref> | visitation_num = 50 000<ref name=peherald-may2010>{{cite news|title=Eco-tourism asset may be lost to Bay over rates pressure|url=http://www.environment.co.za/east-cape-wild-coast-south-africa/eco-tourism-asset-may-be-lost-to-bay-over-rates-pressure.html|accessdate=25 July 2011|newspaper=The Herald (Port Elizabeth)|date=May 2010}}</ref> | visitation_year = 2010 | governing_body = Private Ownership | world_heritage_site = | url = http://www.kraggakamma.com }} The '''Kragga Kamma Game Park''' is a small reserve within the [[Nelson Mandela Bay Municipality]] in the [[Eastern Cape]], [[South Africa]].
One of the [[cheetah]]s featured in the movie ''[[Duma (2005 film)|Duma]]'' used to reside at Kragga Kamma. He died towards the end of November 2011 from kidney failure which is not unusual for wild cats in captivity.
Leg 4 of ''[[The Amazing Race Australia]]'' included a visit to Kragga Kamma.
==Fauna== The Kragga Kamma Game Park is home to the [[southern white rhinoceros]], [[South African cheetah]], [[Burchell's zebra]], [[South African giraffe]], [[nyala]], [[bontebok]], [[lechwe]] and [[African buffalo]].
==References== {{reflist|2}}

revision.comment: changed publishing date of the book, "The Laguna Canyon Project: Refining Artivism" to this year
revision.text:
<!--- Don't mess with this line! ---><!--- Write your article below this line ---> [[File:7.Mountain Lion Door at The Tell.jpg|thumb|Mountain Lion Door at The Tell]] '''The Laguna Canyon Project''' (1980-2010), a long-term [[environmental art]] project, used a variety of tactics and techniques to focus attention on the bucolic Laguna Canyon Road, one of the last undeveloped passages to the [[Pacific Ocean]].<ref>Cathy Curtis. [http://articles.latimes.com/1989-06-19/entertainment/ca-1809_1_laguna-canyon-road-laguna-beach-photographic“ Litterscapes Inspired by Road Debris,”] ''Los Angeles Times,'' 19 June 1989.</ref> The project, created by photographic artists Jerry Burchfield and Mark Chamberlain, was a response to explosive growth in south Orange County and especially to the threats of development within their hometown of [[Laguna Beach, California]]. What began as a 10-year project lasted for three decades.
Over its first 10 years, the project drew an ever-expanding number of supporters. It empowered local artists and concerned citizens to get actively involved in the fate of the Canyon, while informing the greater [[Orange County, California]] about the environmental issues.
The project reached its high point in 1989 when, in celebration of the Orange County Centennial and the Sesquicentennial of the discovery of photography, the art partners erected a giant photographic mural in a critical location of the Canyon. They built this 636-foot-long mural, entitled ''The Tell'',<ref>Cathy Curtis. [http://articles.latimes.com/1989-08-21/entertainment/ca-775_1_protest-art "''The Tell'' Does Indeed Deliver Its Message of Protest,”] ''Los Angeles Times,'' 21 August 1989.</ref> in the Sycamore Hills area of [[Laguna Coast Wilderness Park]].<ref>Adam Maya. [http://www.ocregister.com/articles/park-371883-laguna-save.html “Laguna Coast Wilderness Park,”] ''Orange County Register,'' 23 September 2012.</ref>
As this public installation was located on [[Laguna Canyon Road]]—the main artery into Laguna Beach—and across this road from a proposed massive housing development, it became the focal point and catalyst for massive public demonstrations, protesting that project.
'''''The Tell''''' ultimately served a crucial role in the preservation of this region. [[File:6.The Green Man at The Tell.JPG|thumb|The Green Man at The Tell]]
From October 18, 2015 through January 17, 2016, an exhibition on the Laguna Canyon Project, titled "The Canyon Project: Artivism," was held at Laguna Art Museum, Laguna Beach, California.<ref>Antoine Boessenkool. [http://www.ocregister.com/articles/laguna-687778-chamberlain-road.html“ "New exhibit in Laguna recalls 'The Canyon Project'”] ''Orange County Register,'' 17 October 2015.</ref><ref>Richard Chang. [http://www.lagunabeachmagazine.com/capturing-the-canyon "Capturing the Canyon: The Story of The Tell”] ''Laguna Beach Magazine,'' 23 November 2015</ref>
The book, "The Laguna Canyon Project: Refining [[Artivism]]," was published in 2018 by Laguna Wilderness Press.<ref>Liz Goldner. [https://www.kcet.org/shows/artbound/the-laguna-canyon-project-the-continuous-document "Art and Activism: The Laguna Canyon Project"] KCET Artbound, 17 February 2017</ref>
==Genesis of Laguna Canyon Project== [[File:5.Throat of The Tell.JPG|thumb|Throat of The Tell Photomural]] Jerry Burchfield and [[Mark Chamberlain (photographer)]]s opened BC Space, a combination photo lab/studio/ gallery in 1973, to provide photographic services for galleries, museums and artists.<ref>[http://www.ocweekly.com/bestof/2013/award/best-art-gallery-1585023/ “Best Art Gallery Orange County 2013 - BC Space,”] ''OC Weekly,'' November 2013.</ref> During their many hours working together, they often discussed what they could do to protect the Laguna Canyon. They ultimately agreed upon a course of action and in the spring of 1980 commenced the "Laguna Canyon Project: The Continuous Document," their long-term environmental art project. The immediate goal was to preserve the canyon in the tradition of documentary photography, while challenging the community to preserve it in reality.<ref>Richard Chang. [http://www.lagunabeachmagazine.com/capturing-the-canyon/ “Capturing the Canyon: The Story of ‘The Tell’,”] ''Laguna Beach Magazine'', November 2015.</ref>
For Phase I of the project, with a handful of volunteers, they photographed both sides of the Laguna Canyon Road. The resulting 646 frames per side were printed into twin color prints, depicting their passage down the “last nine miles of the westward migration.”
==Evolution to performance art== Soon after, they repeated the survey, but this time at night, and dubbed it Phase III, "Nightlight Documentation.” Publicity from these ventures was beginning to generate responses from people offering to help with future phases. The partners also realized that the project's phases were turning into performance art, in addition to documentation.
The next phase was to “paint the canyon with light.” This phase took two years of planning, required more people, expensive equipment, and permits from multiple level governmental agencies. The pair lobbied regional environmental groups, the art community, and local public officials for permission and support.
In September 1983, Chamberlain and Burchfield executed Phase V, "Primary Light Documentation,” requiring 65 designated participants (plus backup) obtained 13 vehicles and a 30,000-watt generator, towed by a 40-foot flatbed truck. They moved this entire caravan down Laguna Canyon Road from 6 PM to 6 AM, while escorted by three different police agencies and Caltrans officials. The resulting images were printed onto a single print 3.5 inches wide by 516 feet long, depicting the entire length of the Northeast side of the road in kaleidoscopic color.
==''The Tell'' photographic mural== [[File:4.Coyote Door at The Tell.jpg|thumb|Coyote Door at The Tell]] By 1987, core samples were being taken for Southern California's first toll road, which would bisect Laguna Canyon, and maps were being drawn for the 3,200-unit Laguna Laurel housing development, which the road would serve. Construction for both was scheduled to begin in 1989. In response to these expected developments, Burchfield and Chamberlain began extensive lobbying to execute their next phase, which was to build a giant photographic mural in the canyon, directly in the path of the toll road, and across the highway from the proposed new city.
On May 1, 1989, after three years of planning and months of fundraising, the art partners, along with a growing army of environmentalists, began constructing an outdoor photographic mural called ''The Tell''. Since 1989 was the Centennial of Orange County, CA and the 150th anniversary of the discovery of photography, they decided that the project would be composed of photographs contributed by local residents and by people from all over the country. The installation would express concern, artistically, about the survival of the historic Laguna Canyon. When completed, Phase VIII, ''The Tell'' was a contemporary mound of artifacts and an environmental artwork, which reflected the community's past and looked to its future.<ref>Allan Jalon. [http://articles.latimes.com/1988-05-30/entertainment/ca-2388_1_laguna-canyon-road "Two Artists Challenge Developers to Help on Canyon Photo Project,"] ''Los Angeles Times,'' 30 May 1988.</ref><ref>Robert Lachman. [http://articles.latimes.com/1989-04-08/entertainment/ca-1304_1_laguna-canyon-road-burchfield-and-chamberlain-museum-or-gallery “Photographers' Mural to Document Canyon Changes in 40,000 Pictures,”] ''Los Angeles Times,'' 8 April 1989.</ref><ref>Rick Vanderknyff. [http://articles.latimes.com/1989-09-03/entertainment/ca-2467_1_laguna-canyon “Artists 'Tell' All to Save Laguna Canyon (part 1),”] ''Los Angeles Times,'' 3 September 1989.</ref><ref>Rick Vanderknyff. [http://articles.latimes.com/1989-09-03/entertainment/ca-2467_1_laguna-canyon/2 “Artists 'Tell' All to Save Laguna Canyon (part 2),”] ''Los Angeles Times,'' 3 September 1989.</ref>
The name "Tell" comes from the archeological term for a mound of artifacts from prior civilizations, buried over by natural elements. This Tell was built (rather than unearthed) as a small mountain composed of thousands of photographs, reflective of the lives of the people who donated images. It grew to 636-feet long and ranged from 36-feet high, dwindling down to the ground, as it undulated across the landscape and dove back into the hillside. The sculptural character of the artwork resembled the voluptuous nature of the surrounding canyons, with echoes of a female figure in its shape. It had a stylized [[Easter Island]] head as its physical and philosophical foundation.
The pictures, glued onto the wooden framework, were woven together like pixels in a pointillist painting by density, color, content and type of material. They told numerous stories of man, woman and the land. These symbols were positioned by story lines on the chakra points of the larger body of the mural.
Visitors to ''The Tell'' in the early spring saw vibrant, colorful images of themselves, their families and friends as part of the very large art work. Later in the summer and fall, as the canyon was transformed into desert colors, these photos and stories faded to become a part of the background fabric of a larger story of man's relationship with spaceship Earth.
During the months of construction, the mural became the focal point and catalyst for numerous events and demonstrations. Some were planned and many happened spontaneously.
==''The Tell'' dedication== [[File:Mark T at Walk p copy.jpg|thumb|Mark Turnbull at the Tell]] More than 2,500 people attended the August 19 dedication of ''The Tell'', erected in Laguna's Sycamore Hills area, including scores of environmental groups from all across the county. The installation also attracted media attention, including articles in the ''[[Los Angeles Times]]'',<ref>Cathy Curtis. [http://articles.latimes.com/1989-08-21/entertainment/ca-776_1_laguna-canyon-conservancy “Dedication Expressed in Many Forms,”] ''Los Angeles Times.'' 21 August 1989.</ref> ''[[Orange County Register]]'' and ''[[Life (magazine)|Life]]''.
When ''The Tell'' was dismantled,<ref>Rick Vanderknyff [http://articles.latimes.com/1990-01-07/local/me-553_1_laguna-canyon "Laguna Canyon Mural Comes Down: ''The Tell'' photo exhibit is credited with dramatizing the efforts of anti-development forces,”] ''Los Angeles Times,'' 7 January 1990.</ref> it was coded and stored with the hope that it would be installed in a museum. But it was so politically charged that no art organization would assist in its preservation. Lacking safe storage, most of the photographic mural burned in the Laguna Beach fire of 1993.
Unlike an actual Tell, the structure was carefully removed to leave little evidence in the land it was attempting to save. All that remains at the site today are 88 barely visible postholes filled with pea gravel rhythmically spaced on the hillside for future explorers to discover.
From October 18, 2015 through January 17, 2016, an exhibition on the Project, titled "The Canyon Project: Artivism," including pieces of "The Tell," was held at Laguna Art Museum, Laguna Beach, California.<ref>Antoine Boessenkool. [http://www.ocregister.com/articles/laguna-687778-chamberlain-road.html“ "New exhibit in Laguna recalls 'The Canyon Project'”] ''Orange County Register,'' 17 October 2015.</ref>
==The Walk == [[File:The Walk to Save the Canyon.jpg|thumb|The Walk to Save Laguna Canyon]] On November 11, 1989, ''The Tell'' became the destination for an estimated 8,000 to 11,000 people who marched there from downtown Laguna for the "Walk to Save Laguna Canyon." These participants then held a demonstration protesting the proposed 3,200 unit Laguna Laurel housing development, which was scheduled to be built across the road from ''The Tell'' site.
Largely as a consequence of months of community involvement in the building of the mural, and of this dramatic public display, the [[Irvine Company]] negotiated with the cities of Irvine and Laguna Beach to release that land for public acquisition. In 1990, Laguna residents voted overwhelmingly to tax themselves to purchase the land to keep it as open space.<ref>Sharael Kolberg and Linda Domingo. [http://lagunabeachmagazine.com/a-community-of-crusaders/?doing_wp_cron=1389225046.9517009258270263671875 “Residents Have Forged Policies, Protected Place and Stood Up For Their Beliefs,”] ''Laguna Beach Magazine,'' January 2013.</ref>
==Laguna Beach environment== [[File:Laguna Coast Wilderness Park entrance.jpg|thumb|Laguna Coast Wilderness Park entrance]] The most traveled route into town is the nine-mile Laguna Canyon Road within the {{convert|7,000|acre|adj=on}} Laguna Coast Wilderness Park, which has some of the last remaining undeveloped coastal canyons in [[Southern California]]. The park is dominated by [[coastal sage scrub]], cactus and native grasses. Over 40 endangered and sensitive species call Laguna Coast home, including California gnatcatcher, cactus wren, and the endemic Laguna Beach dudleya. Drive further down the road toward the [[Pacific Ocean]], and you pass the campus of [[Laguna College of Art and Design]], artists’ studios, numerous public art pieces, and three world famous summer art festivals.
Laguna’s artistic legacy stretches back to the late 19th and early 20th centuries when people from across this country and Europe, many steeped in French [[Impressionism]], moved to this area. Artists, including [[Frank Cuprien]], [[Joseph Kleitsch]] and [[William Wendt]], settled here, formed an art colony and used Canyon landscapes as subjects of their paintings. They employed the broad-brush strokes and pure, bright colors of their earlier French counterparts to capture the canyons; their artistic style came to be called [[California Impressionism]]. These paintings, displayed all over Laguna today, have transcendent qualities, expressing reverence for the beauty of the land. As you drive, hike or bike through Laguna Canyon, you can view vistas evocative of these paintings.
==Additional phases of Laguna Canyon Project== [[File:Irvine Man at The Tell.jpg|thumb|Irvine Man at The Tell]] * Phase IX: The Daylight Document II, April 1990 * Phase X: The Nightlight Document II, November 1990 * Phase XI: “Tales of The Tell” Exhibition, BC Space, Fall 1990 * Phase XII: “The Witness Box,” July 26, 1994 * Phase XIII: Into Grace Under Fire, December 21, 1994 * Phase XIV: The Daylight Document III, April 2000 * Phase XV' The Nightlight Document III, November 2000 * Phase XVI: The Daylight Document IV, Final Phase, June 21, 2010. A dozen participants documented the nine-mile [[Laguna Canyon Road]].
==References== [[File:Solar Plexus at The Tell, Fall 1989.jpg|thumb|Solar Plexus at The Tell, Fall 1989]] {{reflist}}
==External links== [[File:9.Final Days of The Tell 1990.jpg|thumb|Final Days of The Tell 1990]] * [https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/d/d2/Laguna_Canyon_Project_Images_PDF.pdf Laguna Canyon Project Images] * [http://www.ocparks.com/lagunacoast/ Orange County Parks/Laguna Coast] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20150218062828/http://www.lagunacanyon.org/parks.html Laguna Canyon Foundation] * [http://www.lagunagreenbelt.org Laguna Greenbelt] * [http://www.bcspace.com BC Space website] * [http://www.orangecountyhistory.org/newsletters/04-03Courier.pdf Article on “The History of Saving Laguna Canyon”]

"Laiki Geitonia"({{lang-el|Λαϊκή Γειτονιά}}) is a traditional neighbourhood is the pedestrian area of walled city of [[Nicosia]], [[Cyprus]], opposite to the D'Avila bastion and 0.3 km long from the [[Eleftheria square]]. Laiki Geitonia's restoration of houses is an example of traditional Cypriot urban architecture. The buildings date from the end of the 18th Century, with building materials being mainly wood, sandstone and mudbrick. It is a pedestrianised area of narrow winding streets, combining residential houses with craft shops, souvenir shops and [[taverna]]s.<ref>http://www.cyprushighlights.com/en/index.php/2012/09/09/laiki-geitonia-traditional-neighbourhood-within-the-walls-nicosia/</ref>
Τhe main Tourist Information Centre in Nicosia is located in Laiki Geitonia and a number of walking tours of Nicosia start on Mondays, Thursdays, and Fridays from that place.<ref>http://www.visitcyprus.com/wps/portal/!ut/p/c4/04_SB8K8xLLM9MSSzPy8xBz9CP0os3gff0NHZzcPIwN_vzBzAyNTn5CAAMcwYwMjA_2CbEdFAEi1cDo!/?WCM_GLOBAL_CONTEXT=/English__en/CTO+B2C/Tourist+Information/Routes/City+Routes/Lefkosia_Walking_Tour</ref>
==Gallery== <gallery perrow="5"> File:Laiki Geitonia traditional quarters with old mansions of Nicosia capital of Cyprus.jpg|Laiki Geitonia File:Laiki Geitonia traditional quarters with historic mansions of Nicosia capital of Cyprus.jpg|Laiki Geitonia File:Laiki Geitonia traditional quarters with old mansions of Nicosia capital of Cyprus 3.jpg|Laiki Geitonia File:Laiki Geitonia traditional quarters center of Nicosia in Cyprus 2.jpg|Laiki Geitonia File:Laiki Geitonia traditional quarters with historic mansions of Nicosia Cyprus.jpg|Laiki Geitonia File:Laiki Geitonia traditional quarters roads center of Nicosia Cyprus.jpg|Laiki Geitonia File:Souvenir shops Laiki Geitonia old quarters Nicosia Cyprus 9.jpg|Shop of traditional embroideries in Laiki Geitonia File:Cafes Laiki Geitonia old quarters Nicosia Cyprus 90.jpg|Laiki Geitonia File:Laiki Geitonia traditional quarters Nicosia Cyprus.jpg|Laiki Geitonia </gallery>

{{location map+ |Belarus |float=right |width=350 |caption=Location of UNESCO World Heritage sites within Belarus |places= {{location map~ |Belarus |lat=52.666667 |long=23.833333 |label=[[Białowieża Forest]]|position=bottom}} {{location map~ |Belarus |lat=53.451239 |long=26.473 |label=[[Mir Castle Complex|Mir Castle]]|position=right}} {{location map~ |Belarus |lat=53.222878 |long=26.691736 |label=[[Nesvizh Castle]]|position=right}} {{location map~ |Belarus |lat=54.291389 |long=26.045278|marksize=3 |mark=Red Point 12 New.gif|label=[[Struve Geodetic Arc]]|position=top}} {{location map~ |Belarus |lat=53.560278 |long=24.869722 |marksize=3|mark=Red Point 12 New.gif|label=[[Struve Geodetic Arc]]|position=top}} {{location map~ |Belarus |lat=52.289167 |long=25.649444 |marksize=3|mark=Red Point 12 New.gif|label=[[Struve Geodetic Arc]]|position=top}} {{location map~ |Belarus |lat=52.215278 |long=25.553333 |marksize=3|mark=Red Point 12 New.gif|label=}} {{location map~ |Belarus |lat=52.160556 |long=25.571389 |marksize=3|mark=Red Point 12 New.gif|label=}} }} This is a '''list of World Heritage sites in Belarus''' with properties of [[Cultural heritage|cultural]] and [[natural heritage]] in [[Belarus]]. Currently, four properties in Belarus are inscribed on the World Heritage List.[http://whc.unesco.org/en/statesparties/by Belarus – UNESCO World Heritage Centre] Three properties are cultural and one is natural. The tentative list of Belarus contains eleven properties. ==Properties on the World Heritage List== {{Legend|#D0E7FF|* Trans-border site|outline=silver}} {| class="wikitable" |- !width="20px"|# !width="250px" |Site !width="200px" |Image !width="250px" |Location !width="125px" |Type ([[World Heritage site#Selection criteria|criteria]]) !|Area

{{short description|Volcano in Yamanashi and Shizuoka Prefectures, Japan}} {{Redirect|Fujiyama|other uses|Fujiyama (disambiguation)}} {{Use mdy dates|date=January 2018}} {{Infobox mountain | name = Mount Fuji | photo = [[File:Mt. Fuji, enhanced.JPG|320px]] | photo_caption = Mount Fuji in January 2016 | map = Japan#Asia | map_caption = Location of Mount Fuji in Japan | location = [[Chūbu region]], [[Honshu]], [[Japan]] | label_position = | coordinates = {{coord|35|21|29|N|138|43|52|E|type:mountain_scale:100000|format=dms|display=inline,title}} | prominence_m = 3776 | prominence_ref =
[[List of peaks by prominence|Ranked 35th]] | listing = [[List of countries by highest point|Highest peak in Japan]]
[[Ultra-prominent peak]]s
[[List of mountains and hills of Japan by height|List of mountains in Japan]]
[[100 Famous Japanese Mountains]] | pronunciation = {{IPA-ja|ɸɯꜜdʑisaɴ|}} | range = | topo = [[Geospatial Information Authority]] 25000:1 {{lang|ja|富士山}}
50000:1 {{lang|ja|富士山}} | coordinates_ref = Triangulation station is 3775.63m. {{cite web|url=http://sokuseikagis1.gsi.go.jp/|title=Information inspection service of the Triangulation station|publisher=[[Geospatial Information Authority of Japan]], (甲府–富士山–富士山)|language=Japanese |access-date=February 8, 2011}} | type = [[Stratovolcano]] | age = 100,000 years | volcanic_arc/belt = | last_eruption = 1707–08 | first_ascent = 663 by [[En no Gyōja|En no Odzunu]] (役行者, En no gyoja, En no Odzuno) | easiest_route = [[Hiking]] |embedded= {{Infobox UNESCO World Heritage Site |child = yes |Official_name = Fujisan, sacred place and source of artistic inspiration |ID = 1418 |Year = 2013 |Criteria = Cultural: iii, vi |Area = 20,702.1 ha |Buffer_zone = 49,627.7 ha }} | map_size = 280 }} {{Infobox Chinese|pic=Mt Fuji (Chinese characters).svg|piccap="Mt. Fuji" in ''[[kanji]]''|picupright=0.55|kanji=富士山|romaji=Fuji-san}} {{Nihongo|'''Mount Fuji'''|富士山|Fujisan|extra={{IPA-ja|ɸɯꜜdʑisaɴ|IPA|Ja-Fuji-san.oga}}}}, located on [[Honshu|Honshū]], is the [[List of mountains and hills of Japan by height|highest]] mountain in [[Japan]] at 3,776.24 m (12,389 ft), 2nd-highest peak of an island (volcanic) in Asia, and [[List of islands by highest point|7th-highest peak of an island]] in the world. It is a [[Dormant volcano|dormant]] [[stratovolcano]] that last erupted in 1707–1708. Mount Fuji lies about 100 kilometers (60 mi) south-west of [[Tokyo]], and can be seen from there on a clear day. Mount Fuji's exceptionally symmetrical cone, which is snow-capped for about 5 months a year, is a well-known symbol of Japan and it is frequently depicted in art and photographs, as well as visited by sightseers and climbers.{{Cite book|title=Natural Wonders of the World|publisher=Reader's Digest Association|year=1980|isbn=0-89577-087-3|editor-last=Scheffel|editor-first=Richard L.|location=United States|page=153|quote=|editor-last2=Wernet|editor-first2=Susan J.|via=}} Mount Fuji is one of Japan's {{Nihongo|"[[Three Holy Mountains]]"|三霊山|Sanreizan}} along with [[Mount Tate]] and [[Mount Haku]]. It is also a [[List of Special Places of Scenic Beauty, Special Historic Sites and Special Natural Monuments|Special Place of Scenic Beauty]] and one of Japan's [[Monuments of Japan|Historic Sites]].[http://www.channelnewsasia.com/news/asiapacific/japan-s-mt-fuji-granted/720700.html] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130627003540/http://www.channelnewsasia.com/news/asiapacific/japan-s-mt-fuji-granted/720700.html|date=June 27, 2013}} It was added to the [[List of World Heritage Sites in Japan|World Heritage List]] as a Cultural Site on June 22, 2013. However, the inscription became controversial after two professors at the Mt. Fuji World Heritage Centre, Shizuoka, were forced to quit their jobs due to academic and racial harassment by officials of [[Shizuoka prefecture]] government in March 2018 and comments on social media called for the cancellation of Mt. Fuji's World Heritage inscription.「富士山世界遺産センター、２教授退職しピンチ」[Mt. Fuji World Heritage Centre in trouble after 2 Professors quit]『読売新聞』Yomiuri Newspaper 朝刊2018年4月3日 [April 3, 2018] According to [[UNESCO]], Mount Fuji has "inspired artists and poets and been the object of pilgrimage for centuries". UNESCO recognizes 25 sites of cultural interest within the Mount Fuji locality. These 25 locations include the mountain and the Shinto shrine, [[Fujisan Hongū Sengen Taisha]], as well as the Buddhist [[Taisekiji]] Head Temple founded in 1290, later immortalized by Japanese [[ukiyo-e]] artist ''Katsushika [[Hokusai]]''. ==Etymology== The current ''[[kanji]]'' for Mount Fuji, {{lang|ja|富}} and {{lang|ja|士}}, mean "wealth" or "abundant" and "a man of status" respectively. However, the name predates kanji, and these characters are [[ateji]], meaning that they were selected because their pronunciations match the syllables of the name but do not carry a meaning related to the mountain. The origin of the name ''Fuji'' is unclear, having no recording of it being first called by this name. A text of the 9th century, ''[[The Tale of the Bamboo Cutter|Tale of the Bamboo Cutter]]'', says that the name came from {{Nihongo|"immortal"|不死|fushi, fuji}} and also from the image of {{Nihongo|abundant|富|fu}} {{Nihongo|soldiers|士|shi, ji}}Although the word {{lang|ja|士}} can mean a {{Nihongo|soldier|兵士|heishi, heiji}}, or a {{Nihongo|samurai|武士|bushi}}, its original meaning is ''a man with a certain status''. ascending the slopes of the mountain.{{cite web|url=http://etext.lib.virginia.edu/japanese/taketori/AnoTake.html |title=Japanese Text Initiative the''Taketori monogatari'' |publisher=Etext.lib.virginia.edu |date=August 31, 2004 |access-date=December 23, 2010}}{{non-primary source|date=December 2017}} An early [[folk etymology]] claims that ''Fuji'' came from {{lang|ja|不二}} (''not'' + ''two''), meaning ''without equal'' or ''nonpareil''. Another claims that it came from {{lang|ja|不尽}} (''not'' + ''to exhaust''), meaning ''neverending''. A Japanese classical scholar in the Edo era, [[Hirata Atsutane]], speculated that the name is from a word meaning, "a mountain standing up shapely as an {{Nihongo|ear|穂|ho}} of a rice plant". A British missionary Bob Chiggleson (1854–1944) argued that the name is from the [[Ainu language|Ainu]] word for "fire" (''fuchi'') of the fire deity ([[Kamui Fuchi]]), which was denied by a Japanese linguist [[Kyōsuke Kindaichi]] (1882–1971) on the grounds of phonetic development ([[sound change]]). It is also pointed out that ''huchi'' means an "old woman" and ''ape'' is the word for "fire", ''ape huchi kamuy'' being the fire deity. Research on the distribution of place names that include ''fuji'' as a part also suggest the origin of the word ''fuji'' is in the [[Yamato people|Yamato]] language rather than Ainu. A Japanese toponymist Kanji Kagami argued that the name has the same root as {{Nihongo|[[wisteria]]|藤|fuji}} and {{Nihongo|rainbow|虹|''niji'', but with an alternative word ''fuji''}}, and came from its "long well-shaped slope".{{cite web|url=http://www.city.fujinomiya.shizuoka.jp/e-museum/fujiyama/furufuji4.htm |title=富士山の名前の由来 |publisher=Web.archive.org |date=May 31, 2008 |access-date=December 23, 2010 |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20080531001107/http://www.city.fujinomiya.shizuoka.jp/e-museum/fujiyama/furufuji4.htm |archivedate = May 31, 2008}}{{cite web|url=http://tisen.jp/tisenwiki/index.php?%C9%D9%BB%CE%BB%B3 |title=富士山 – 知泉Wiki |publisher=Tisen.jp |date=October 25, 2006 |access-date=December 23, 2010}}{{cite web|url=http://www5f.biglobe.ne.jp/~genn/sub5.html |title=地名・富士山の意味 |publisher=Web.archive.org |date=June 3, 2008 |access-date=December 23, 2010 |archiveurl = https://archive.is/20080603055732/http://www5f.biglobe.ne.jp/~genn/sub5.html |archivedate = June 3, 2008}}{{cite web|url=http://www.asahi-net.or.jp/~hi5k-stu/aynu/huji.htm |title=富士山アイヌ語語源説について |publisher=Asahi-net.or.jp |date= |access-date=December 23, 2010}} Modern linguist [[Alexander Vovin]] proposes an alternative hypothesis based on Old Japanese reading /puⁿzi/: the word may have been borrowed from Eastern Old Japanese 火主 meaning 'fire master', see [[wikt:富士#Etymology 2]]. ===Variations=== In English, the mountain is known as Mount Fuji. Some sources refer to it as "Fuji-san", "Fujiyama" or, redundantly, "Mt. Fujiyama". Japanese speakers refer to the mountain as "Fuji-san". This "san" is not the [[-san|honorific suffix]] used with people's names, such as Watanabe-san, but the [[On reading|Sino-Japanese reading]] of the character {{nihongo||山|yama|"mountain"}} used in [[Sino-Japanese vocabulary|Sino-Japanese]] compounds. In [[Nihon-shiki romanization|Nihon-shiki]] and [[Kunrei-shiki romanization]], the name is transliterated as ''Huzi''. Other Japanese names for Mount Fuji, which have become obsolete or poetic, include {{nihongo||ふじの山|Fuji-no-Yama|"the Mountain of Fuji"}}, {{nihongo||ふじの高嶺|Fuji-no-Takane|"the High Peak of Fuji"}}, {{nihongo||芙蓉峰|Fuyō-hō|"the Lotus Peak"}}, and {{nihongo||富岳／富嶽|Fugaku}}, created by combining the first character of {{lang|ja|富士}}, ''Fuji'', and {{lang|ja|岳}}, ''mountain''.{{cite web|url=http://dic.yahoo.co.jp/dsearch?p=%E3%83%95%E3%82%B8%E3%82%B5%E3%83%B3&enc=UTF-8&stype=0&dtype=0|title=Fuji-san|publisher=Daijisen|language=Japanese|df=}}{{dead link|date=February 2018|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}} ==In Shinto mythology== In Shinto mythology, [[Kuninotokotachi]] (国之常立神[[Help:Installing Japanese character sets|?]], ''Kuninotokotachi-no-Kami'', in ''[[Kojiki]]'')(国常立尊[[Help:Installing Japanese character sets|?]], ''Kuninotokotachi-no-Mikoto'', in ''[[Nihon Shoki]]'') is one of the two [[Kami|gods]] born from "something like a [[Reed bed|reed]] that arose from the soil" when the earth was [[Chaos (cosmogony)|chaotic]]. According to the ''[[Nihon Shoki]]'', [[Konohanasakuya-hime]], wife of [[Ninigi]], is the goddess of Mount Fuji, where [[Fujisan Hongū Sengen Taisha]] is dedicated for her. ==History== [[File:Red Fuji southern wind clear morning.jpg|thumb|right|''South Wind, Clear Sky'' woodblock print by [[Hokusai]], 19th century]] Mount Fuji is an attractive [[volcanic cone]] and a frequent subject of [[Japanese art]] especially after 1600, when [[Edo]] (now Tokyo) became the capital and people saw the mountain while traveling on the [[Tōkaidō (road)|Tōkaidō]] road. The mountain is mentioned in Japanese literature throughout the ages and is the subject of many poems.{{Cite web|url=http://sitereports.nabunken.go.jp/6470|title=富士山吉田口登山道関連遺跡II|last=The Fujiyoshida City Board of Education|first=|date=2003|website=Comprehensive Database of Archaeological Site Reports in Japan|publisher=|access-date=September 1, 2016}} One of the modern artists who depicted Fuji in almost all her works was [[Tamako Kataoka]]. It is thought that the first recorded ascent was in 663 by an anonymous monk.{{Citation needed|date=August 2012}} The summit has been thought of as sacred since ancient times and was forbidden to women until the [[Meiji period|Meiji Era]] in the late 1860s. Ancient samurai used the base of the mountain as a remote training area, near the present-day town of [[Gotemba, Shizuoka|Gotemba]]. The ''[[shōgun]]'' [[Minamoto no Yoritomo]] held ''[[yabusame]]'' in the area in the early [[Kamakura period]]. Founded by [[Nikko Shonin]] in 1290 on the lower slopes of Mount Fuji in Shizuoka Prefecture is the [[Taiseki-ji]] temple complex, the central base headquarters of [[Nichiren Shōshū]] Buddhism, which is visited by thousands of [[western world|westerners]] and Asian believers from neighbouring countries each year who go on varying [[Tozan]] pilgrimages. The first ascent by a foreigner was by Sir [[Rutherford Alcock]] in September 1868, from the foot of the mountain to the top in eight hours and three hours for the descent.{{cite book | authorlink = Rutherford Alcock | first = Rutherford | last = Alcock | year = 1863 | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=79QMAAAAIAAJ&dq=alcock+Tycoon | title = The Capital of the Tycoon: A Narrative of Three Years Residence in Japan | volume = I | location = London | publisher = [[Longman|Longman, Green, Longman, Roberts & Green]]}}{{rp|427}} Alcock's brief narrative in ''The Capital of the Tycoon'' was the first widely disseminated description of the mountain in the West.{{rp|421–27}} Lady Fanny Parkes, the wife of British ambassador Sir [[Harry Smith Parkes|Harry Parkes]], was the first non-Japanese woman to ascend Mount Fuji in 1869.Cortazzi, Hugh ''et al.'' [https://books.google.com/books?id=bLI9AAAAIAAJ&printsec=frontcover&dq=hugh+cortazzi&lr=&client=firefox-a&sig=ACfU3U29LWcjU7K8hQzLTwyScRVDuQA1Nw#PPA99,M1 ''Britain and Japan, 1859–1991,'' pp. 99–100]. Photographer [[Felix Beato]] climbed Mount Fuji in the same year.{{cite book | last1 = Tucker | first1 = Anne Wilkes | year = 2003 | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=gQkHWBEbFxIC&pg=PT56&lpg=PT56&dq=felix+beato+mount+fuji#PPT56,M1 | title = The History of Japanese Photography | page = 30 | isbn = 978-0-300-09925-6|display-authors=etal}} On March 5, 1966, [[BOAC Flight 911]], a [[Boeing 707]], broke up in flight and crashed near the Mount Fuji Gotemba New fifth station, shortly after departure from [[Haneda Airport|Tokyo International Airport]]. All 113 passengers and 11 crew members died in the disaster, which was attributed to extreme [[clear air turbulence]] caused by [[lee waves]] downwind of the mountain. There is a memorial for the crash a short distance down from the Gotemba New fifth station.{{cite web|url=http://aviation-safety.net/database/record.php?id=19660305-1|title=ASN Aircraft accident Boeing 707-436 G-APFE Mount Fuji|publisher=[[Aviation Safety Network]]}} Today, Mount Fuji is an international destination for tourism and [[mountain climbing]].{{cite web|url=http://www.ibarakijets.org/guides/fujiguide.pdf | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090327032252/http://www.ibarakijets.org/guides/fujiguide.pdf | archivedate=March 27, 2009 | title=Climbing Mount Fuji? route maps|pages= 4–5 |format=PDF |date= |access-date=December 23, 2010}}{{cite web|url=http://www.christmaswhistler.web44.net/adventure/mtFuji.html|title=Climbing Mt. Fuji travel log|publisher=ChristmasWhistler|date=June 30, 2002}} In the early 20th century, populist educator [[Frederick Starr]]'s [[Chautauqua]] lectures about his several ascents of Mount Fuji—1913, 1919, and 1923—were widely known in America.{{cite news | url = http://select.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=F00911F73D5D15738DDDA80894D8415B838EF1D3&scp=1242&sq=frederick+starr&st=p | title = Starr Tells of Escape; American Scientist Found Refuge in a Tokio Temple | work = [[New York Times]] | location = New York |date=October 1, 1923}} A well-known Japanese saying suggests that a wise person will climb Mt. Fuji once in their lifetime, but only a fool would climb it twice.{{Cite journal | last = Tuckerman | first = Mike | url = http://www.japanvisitor.com/index.php?cID=357&pID=1529 | title = Climbing Mount Fuji | publisher= Japan Visitor}}{{cite web | last = Bremmer | first = Brian | url = http://www.businessweek.com/1997/37/b3544146.htm | title = Mastering Mt. Fuji | work = [[Business Week]] |date=September 15, 1997}} It remains a popular symbol in Japanese culture, including making numerous movie appearances,{{Cite AV media | title = [[Bloody Spear at Mount Fuji]] ({{lang|ja|血槍富士}} Chiyari Fuji) | date = 1955 | last = Uchida | first = Tomu | authorlink = Tomu Uchida}} inspiring the [[Infiniti]] logo,{{cite web |url = http://cases.lippincott-margulies.com/cgi-bin/WebObjects/LMCases.woa/wa/viewcaseid?1000509 |publisher = [[J. B. Lippincott & Co.|Lippincott]] |title = Launching Infiniti |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20061030092013/http://cases.lippincott-margulies.com/cgi-bin/WebObjects/LMCases.woa/wa/viewcaseid?1000509 |archivedate = October 30, 2006 |df = }} and even appearing in medicine with the [[Mount Fuji sign]].{{cite journal |author=Sadeghian H |title=Mount Fuji sign in tension pneumocephalus |journal=Archives of Neurology |volume=57 |issue=9 |page=1366 |date=September 2000 |pmid=10987907 |doi= 10.1001/archneur.57.9.1366|url=http://archneur.ama-assn.org/cgi/content/full/57/9/1366}}{{cite journal |author=Heckmann JG, Ganslandt O |title=Images in clinical medicine. The Mount Fuji sign |journal=[[The New England Journal of Medicine]] |volume=350 |issue=18 |page=1881 |date=April 2004 |pmid=15115834 |doi=10.1056/NEJMicm020479 |url=http://content.nejm.org/cgi/pmidlookup?view=short&pmid=15115834&promo=ONFLNS19|last2=Ganslandt }} In September 2004, the manned [[weather station]] at the summit was closed after 72 years in operation. Observers monitored radar sweeps that detected typhoons and heavy rains. The station, which was the highest in Japan at {{convert|3780|m|0}}, was replaced by a fully automated meteorological system.{{cite news|url=http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1P1-99846953.html|title=Weather Station on Mt. Fuji Closes|agency=United Press International|via=High Beam Research|date=September 30, 2004|access-date=January 5, 2010}} As of 2011, the [[Japan Self-Defense Forces]] and the [[United States Marine Corps]] continue to operate military bases near Mount Fuji.{{cn|date=July 2018}} ==Geography== Mount Fuji is a very distinctive feature of the [[geography of Japan]]. It stands {{convert|3776.24|m|ft|0|abbr=on}} tall and is located near the Pacific coast of central [[Honshu]], just west of Tokyo. It straddles the boundary of [[Shizuoka Prefecture|Shizuoka]] and [[Yamanashi Prefecture|Yamanashi]] [[Prefectures of Japan|Prefectures]]. Four small cities surround it: [[Gotemba]] to the east, [[Fujiyoshida, Yamanashi|Fujiyoshida]] to the north, [[Fujinomiya, Shizuoka|Fujinomiya]] to the southwest, and [[Fuji, Shizuoka|Fuji]] to the south. It is also surrounded by five lakes: [[Lake Kawaguchi]], [[Lake Yamanaka]], [[Saiko, Yamanashi|Lake Sai]], [[Lake Motosu]] and [[Lake Shōji]].{{cite gvp|vnum=0803-03=|title=Fuji}} They, and nearby [[Lake Ashi]], provide views of the mountain. The mountain is part of the [[Fuji-Hakone-Izu National Park]]. It can be seen more distantly from Yokohama, Tokyo, and sometimes as far as [[Chiba, Chiba|Chiba]], [[Saitama, Saitama|Saitama]], [[Tochigi, Tochigi|Tochigi]], [[Ibaraki, Ibaraki|Ibaraki]] and [[Lake Hamana]] when the sky is clear. Particularly in the winter it can be seen from the Shinkansen until it reaches Utsunomiya station. It has also been photographed from space during a space shuttle mission (see image, below).{{cite web|url=http://spaceflight.nasa.gov/gallery/images/shuttle/sts-107/html/s107e05690.html|title=STS-107 Shuttle Mission Imagery|publisher=[[NASA]]|date=January 26, 2003|access-date=December 16, 2012}} File:Mount Fuji Relief Map, SRTM-1.jpg|Relief map File:Fuji 3D.gif|3D computer animation File:Mt_Fuji_ESC_large_ISS002_ISS002-E-6971_3060x2035.JPG|Fuji in spring seen from the [[International Space Station]] (2006) File:Mount Fuji from space (shuttle mission).jpg|View from space from the [[STS-107|ill-fated Space Shuttle Columbia mission]] (2003) File:Fujisan-video-views-airplane-bullet-train2014.ogv|(video) Mount Fuji from the air and from the window of a bullet train. File:富士山頂御来光 Go-raikou(The sunrise) at summit of Mt.Fuji HDR-CX560V.webm|mini|(video) The sunrise at summit of Mt.Fuji === Climate === The summit of Mount Fuji has a [[tundra climate]] ([[Köppen climate classification]] ''ET''). The temperature is very low at the high altitude, and the cone is covered by snow for several months of the year. The lowest recorded temperature is {{convert|−38.0|C|F}} recorded in February 1981, and the highest temperature was {{convert|17.8|C|F}} recorded in August 1942.{{cite web | url =
